title.narrative: 1.3: Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) AND PEDIATRIC HIV

description.narrative: Government at all levels and communities have increased capacity for providing evidence-based quality Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) and pediatric HIV services to HIV-positive mothers and infants, which contributes to Care And Treatment Of Children Affected By Hiv And Aids, Hiv Prevention, Hiv Prevention (Covid), Hiv â€“ General, Pmtct And Infant Male Circumcision, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment And Care Of Children Living With Hiv. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: At least 80 per cent of pregnant women, new-borns and children less than five years of age and adolescents have access to high- impact quality maternal, new-born, child and adolescent health interventions including HIV and AIDS with a special focus on the most disadvantaged districts and communities.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Government at all levels and communities have increased capacity for providing evidence-based quality PMTCT and pediatric HIVservices to HIV-positive mothers and infants

description.narrative: Currently PMTCT services in South Africa are near universal at eligible health facilities and concurrently the MTCT rate improved to 4.1 per cent in 2018 compared to 6.24 per cent in 2014. Furthermore, 87 per cent of pregnant women living with HIV accessed antiretroviral medicine to prevent transmission of the virus to their baby, preventing 53,000 new HIV infections among newborns. Nonetheless, there were 14,000 new HIV infections in children under 15 years and Just 56 per cent of children needing ART were on treatment and 67 per cent were virally suppressed. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:17/01/2020
